children.value: directive in your schema to use static cache hints.
Apollo Server enables you to define cache control settings (
) for each field in your schema:

type Post {
  id: ID!
  title: String
  author: Author
  votes: Int @cacheControl(maxAge: 30)  comments: [Comment]
  readByCurrentUser: Boolean! @cacheControl(maxAge: 10, scope: PRIVATE)}
When Apollo Server resolves an operation, it calculates the result's correct cache behavior based on the
among the result's fields. You can then use this calculation to support any form of cache implementation you want, such as by providing it to your CDN via a
You can define field-level cache hints
Note that when setting cache hints, it's important to understand:
Which fields of your schema can be cached safely
How long a cached value should remain valid
Whether a cached value is global or user-specific
These details can vary significantly, even among the fields of a single object type.
directive, which you can use in your schema to define caching behavior either for a
directive, you must add the following definitions to your server's schema:

enum CacheControlScope {
  PUBLIC
  PRIVATE
}

directive @cacheControl(
  maxAge: Int
  scope: CacheControlScope
  inheritMaxAge: Boolean
) on FIELD_DEFINITION | OBJECT | INTERFACE | UNION
If you don't add these definitions, Apollo Server throws an
The maximum amount of time the field's cached value is valid, in seconds. The default value is
, the field's value is specific to a single user. The default value is
of its parent field instead of using the
for fields that should usually be cached with the same settings. If caching settings might change at runtime, you can use the
Apollo Server assigns each GraphQL response a
among included fields. If any field has a
, the response will not be cached at all.
Similarly, Apollo Server sets a response's
This example defines cache control settings for two fields of the

type Post {
  id: ID!
  title: String
  author: Author
  votes: Int @cacheControl(maxAge: 30)  comments: [Comment]
  readByCurrentUser: Boolean! @cacheControl(maxAge: 10, scope: PRIVATE)}
field is cached for a maximum of 30 seconds.
field is cached for a maximum of 10 seconds, and its visibility is restricted to a single user.
This example defines cache control settings for

type Post @cacheControl(maxAge: 240) {  id: Int!
  title: String
  author: Author
  votes: Int
  comments: [Comment]
  readByCurrentUser: Boolean!
}
If another object type in this schema includes a field of type
s), that field's value is cached for a maximum of 240 seconds:

type Comment {
  post: Post! # Cached for up to 240 seconds
  body: String!
}
is cached for a maximum of 120 seconds,

type Comment {
  post: Post! @cacheControl(maxAge: 120)
  body: String!
}
You can decide how to cache a particular field's result
you're resolving it. To support this, Apollo Server provides a
If you set a field's cache hint in its resolver, it
method, which you call like so:

const resolvers = {
  Query: {
    post: (_, { id }, _, info) => {
      info.cacheControl.setCacheHint({ maxAge: 60, scope: 'PRIVATE' });      return find(posts, { id });
    }
  }
}
This object represents the field's current cache hint. Its fields include the following:

// If we call this first...
info.cacheControl.setCacheHint({ maxAge: 60, scope: 'PRIVATE' });

// ...then this changes maxAge (more restrictive) but NOT scope (less restrictive)
info.cacheControl.cacheHint.restrict({ maxAge: 30, scope: 'PUBLIC'});
This method enables you to get the default cache hint for a particular object type. This can be useful when resolving a union or interface field, which might return one of multiple object types.
For security, each operation response's cache behavior is calculated based on the
cache hints among the result's fields:
among all fields. If that value is
By default, the following schema fields have a
GraphQL operation includes a root field, this means that by default,
no operation results are cached unless you set cache hints!
Fields that return a non-scalar type
(object, interface, or union) or a list of non-scalar types.
non-root fields that return scalar types

hProperties.aria-label: why are these the maxage defaults permalink

children.value: Our philosophy behind Apollo Server caching is that a response should only be considered cacheable if every part of that response
to being cacheable. At the same time, we don't think developers should have to specify cache hints for every single field in their schema.
Root field resolvers are extremely likely to fetch data (because these fields have no parent), so we set their default
to avoid automatically caching data that
Resolvers for other non-scalar fields (objects, interfaces, and unions)
commonly fetch data because they contain arbitrarily many fields. Consequently, we also set their default
fetch data and instead usually populate data via the
argument. Consequently, these fields inherit their default
from their parent to reduce schema clutter.

Of course, these heuristics aren't always correct! For example, the resolver for a non-root scalar field might indeed fetch remote data. You can always set your own cache hint for any field with an undesirable default behavior.
for every field with a resolver that actually fetches data from a data source (such as a database or REST API).
other fields can then inherit their cache hint from their parent (fields with resolvers that
fetch data less commonly have specific caching needs). For more on this, see

hProperties.aria-label: setting a different default maxage permalink

children.value: that's applied to fields that otherwise receive the
You should identify and address all exceptions to your default
before you enable it in production, but this is a great way to get started with cache control.
by passing the cache control plugin to the

import { ApolloServerPluginCacheControl } from 'apollo-server-core';

const server = new ApolloServer({
  // ...other options...
  plugins: [ApolloServerPluginCacheControl({ defaultMaxAge: 5 })],  // 5 seconds
}));
You usually don't need to specify cache hints for every field in your schema. Instead, we recommend doing the following as a starting point:
for every field with a resolver that
actually fetches data from a data source
(such as a database or REST API). You can base the value of
on the frequency of updates that are made to the relevant data.
for each other non-root field that returns a non-scalar type.
Note that you can only set

type Query {
  book: Book
  cachedBook: Book @cacheControl(maxAge: 60)
  reader: Reader @cacheControl(maxAge: 40)
}

type Book {
  title: String
  cachedTitle: String @cacheControl(maxAge: 30)
}

type Reader {
  book: Book @cacheControl(inheritMaxAge: true)
}
Let's look at some queries and their resulting

# maxAge: 0
# Query.book doesn't set a maxAge and it's a root field (default 0).
query GetBookTitle {
  book {        # 0
    cachedTitle # 30
  }
}

# maxAge: 60
# Query.cachedBook has a maxAge of 60, and Book.title is a scalar, so it
# inherits maxAge from its parent by default.
query GetCachedBookTitle {
  cachedBook { # 60
    title      # inherits
  }
}

# maxAge: 30
# Query.cachedBook has a maxAge of 60, but Book.cachedTitle has
# a maxAge of 30.
query GetCachedBookCachedTitle {
  cachedBook {  # 60
    cachedTitle # 30
  }
}

# maxAge: 40
# Query.reader has a maxAge of 40. Reader.Book is set to
# inheritMaxAge from its parent, and Book.title is a scalar
# that inherits maxAge from its parent by default.
query GetReaderBookTitle {
  reader {  # 40
    book {  # inherits
      title # inherits
    }
  }
}
Using cache control with Apollo Federation requires v0.28 of
in your router, and v3.0.2 of Apollo Server in both servers.

enum may be defined in a subgraph's schema. An Apollo Server-based subgraph will calculate and set the cache hint for the response that it sends to the gateway as it would for a non-federated Apollo Server sending a response to a client. The gateway will then calculate the cache hint for the overall response based on the most restrictive settings among all of the responses received from the subgraphs involved in query plan execution.
type, so all query plans that require entity resolution will have a
. To override this default behavior, you can add a

type Book @key(fields: "isbn") @cacheControl(maxAge: 30) {
  isbn: String!
  title: String
}
field is resolved it will check the applicable concrete type for a cache hint (which would be the
type in the example above) and apply that hint instead.
To set cache hints dynamically, the

hProperties.aria-label: overriding subgraph cache hints in the gateway permalink

children.value: Overriding subgraph cache hints in the gateway
If a subgraph does not specify a

, the gateway will assume its response (and
in turn, the overall response) cannot be cached. To override this behavior, you can set the
Additionally, if the gateway should ignore
response headers from subgraphs that will affect the operation's cache policy, then you can set the

const gateway = new ApolloGateway({
  // ...
  buildService({ url }) {
    return new RemoteGraphQLDataSource({
      url,
      honorSubgraphCacheControlHeader: false;
    });
  }
});
is to have no impact on the cacheability of the response in either direction. In other words, this property won’t determine whether the response can be cached, but it does exclude a subgraph's
header from consideration in the gateway's calculation. If all subgraphs are excluded from consideration when calculating the overall
header, the response sent to the client will not be cached.
Whenever Apollo Server sends an operation response that has a non-zero
HTTP header that describes the response's cache policy.
Cache-Control: max-age=60, private

If you run Apollo Server behind a CDN or another caching proxy, you can configure it to use this header's value to cache responses appropriately. See your CDN's documentation for details (for example, here's the
Because CDNs and caching proxies only cache GET requests (not POST requests, which Apollo Client sends for all operations by default), we recommend enabling
instance. However, most browsers enforce a size limit on GET requests, and large query strings might exceed this limit.
You can prevent Apollo Server from setting

import { ApolloServerPluginCacheControl } from 'apollo-server-core';

const server = new ApolloServer({
  // ...other options...
  plugins: [ApolloServerPluginCacheControl({ calculateHttpHeaders: false })],
}));
If you do this, the cache control plugin still calculates caching behavior for each operation response. You can then use this information with other plugins (like the
To disable cache control calculations entirely, instead install the
plugin (this plugin has no effect other than preventing the cache control plugin from being installed):

import { ApolloServerPluginCacheControlDisabled } from 'apollo-server-core';

const server = new ApolloServer({
  // ...other options...
  plugins: [ApolloServerPluginCacheControlDisabled()],
}));
You can cache Apollo Server query responses in stores like Redis, Memcached, or Apollo Server's in-memory cache.
To set up your in-memory response cache, you first import the

import responseCachePlugin from 'apollo-server-plugin-response-cache';

const server = new ApolloServer({
  // ...other options...
  plugins: [responseCachePlugin()],
});
On initialization, this plugin automatically begins caching responses according to
The plugin uses the same in-memory LRU cache as Apollo Server's other features. For environments with multiple server instances, you might instead want to use a shared cache backend, such as
HTTP header to the number of seconds the returned value has been in the cache.
Using Memcached/Redis as a cache storage backend

hProperties.aria-label: identifying users for private responses permalink

children.value: If a cached response has a
, its value is accessible by only a single user. To enforce this restriction, the cache needs to know how to
To enable this identification, you provide a

import responseCachePlugin from 'apollo-server-plugin-response-cache';
const server = new ApolloServer({
  // ...other settings...
  plugins: [responseCachePlugin({
    sessionId: (requestContext) => (requestContext.request.http.headers.get('session-id') || null),
  })],
});
responses are not cached at all.
The cache uses the return value of this function to identify the user who can later access the cached
response. In the example above, the function uses a
header from the original operation request.
If a client later executes the exact same query
has the same identifier, Apollo Server returns the
cached response if it's still available.

hProperties.aria-label: separating responses for logged in and logged out users permalink

children.value: Separating responses for logged-in and logged-out users
cached responses are accessible by all users. However, if you define a
One version for users with a
One version for users with a
This enables you to cache different responses for logged-in and logged-out users. For example, you might want your page header to display different menu items depending on a user's logged-in status.
, you can provide the following functions to your
to configure cache reads and writes. Each of these functions takes a
(representing the incoming operation) as a parameter.

This function's return value (any JSON-stringifiable object) is added to the key for the cached response. For example, if your API includes translatable text, this function can return a string derived from
the cache for the incoming operation, even if a valid response is available.
, Apollo Server doesn't cache its response for the incoming operation, even if the response's
